title: Why do I get paired with players I report?
body:
So we lost a game. Our Lee Sin decided to sit at base for 7 minutes until we lost. Basically an afk, just not official. On top of that, he was a jerk about it.
So I reported him.

Go to play the next game, and hey, guess who's there! The same Lee Sin! Playing Lee Sin again!

I'm support this game, so I show my intent to play Janna.

What does the Lee Sin do?

Bans Janna.

Of course.

So at the end of the game, I'll report him again. But all of this could have been avoided if the system just didn't pair me with the same person again in the first place.

Seriously, why pair together the people who report each other, but not the people who honor each other? Why does the system do this? Now I'm likely to lose another game with the same person who I already reported for not being very sportsmanlike because of the exact same problem.

Rito please.

replies.body:
If you couldn't get paired with anyone you reported it would increase queue times. At the very top end of ranked play it would be quite abusable because you could just report people better than you and end up getting paired only against weaker players.

Also not everyone who gets reported did something wrong. Not everyone who was reported and did something wrong is going to do it next game. I report people for "gg ez" and a couple other things that don't make me upset to see them next game necessarily but that I do feel shouldn't be happening in League.

I personally think at anything below diamond (on NA, other servers would probably need to be different) it should at the very least make it so you can't end up in a game with them for 6 hours. Maybe just for certain offenses. Hard to say.
I guess that's a fair enough reason.

Then why even respond Hun, if you don't get it?

The point is that you could literally just report anyone you don't want to play with or against for whatever reason. They don't punish you for spamming reports (although your reports may hold less weight in the future, they would still have to be of equal value in a system like this), therefore you could literally just spam report anyone for having a bad game.

The amount of people that would be needlessly reported and the spam that that would cause is enough to completely shut the idea of a system down. 

If you block someone, maybe. I say MAYBE because you could again spam block several players just for the sake of it, but at least it wouldn't clutter reports as much as it would have. Still though, it would be an easily abused system.

If I don't warrant a response, please, do me a favor and don't waste my time.

Okay - have a response.

Lets break it down here. Roughly 10 million active NA players in LOL - lets just say that only 1 million of them are in your player pool. Then lets say you play 4000 games in a season (a ridicules amount of games) if you reported every single player you encountered - you would have only reported 36,000 people out of 1 million - that is under 4% of the total player pool. And that's reporting everyone! If you only report the bad/good players it's an even smaller number that only effects less than 4% of the population! And this comparison covers your typical plat/diamond player (it's a 5x larger pool for bronze silver gold). Furthermore, safeguards could be put in place. Like a report limit, or even the need for 2 reports on a player to validate the report (this would really only be necessary for masters/challenger players anyways). There is a host of things that could be done to make this work BUT people like you always harp on about how it can be abused even though it's statistically impossible to do so.

Literally making a "need for 2 people to report a player" for validation is almost an unnecessary step as you can literally, easily get almost anyone to report anyone for anything because a lot of the player base feels that reports do very little. I'm sure it wouldn't be hard to convince ONE other player to report someone.

My point was that regardless, it would be more trouble than it is worth to actually implement a system like this and clearly define the boundaries. Alternatively, you could EASILY wait a good five minutes before queuing again. The chances that the same toxic player hasn't already found a match is very little, and it will definitely give you a tilt break.

And the tilt break is definitely necessary since literally 75% of the player base takes his GAME way tooooo seriously.
Riot will not change it because people would abuse the system and just start reporting players they thought were bad to prevent getting them on their team again.

What is wrong with this? It doesn't change their MMR - they still get matched at the same level. Literally gives you no advantage, unless of course, the player they are reporting is actually really bad - which is likely. However, in this case, that would be a unintended benefit to the system. There's also another way to prevent abuse. Give a player a limited number of reports per day, like maybe 5. That way they would have to limit their reporting to only serious cases, rather than frivolous reports.

This happened to me before, so when I am playing and get a teammate or team like this, I say to myself "Imma let the queue air out a bit." Hopefully that group will get into champ selects before they end up in my queue again. Also, the problem with the whole honor vs report system is that it would easily be abused. I play against a horrible kid, honor so I can play him again.  I play against a good kid, report so I don't play them again. It's a double edged sword where you could get that horrible person to vs again, but you could also get them on your team. So you honor them to play vs a bad person hopefully, get them on your team next game, then report them so you don't play with them again. It would make the report/honor system useless for anything. It makes sense on paper, but anything outside of putting toxic players into a queue of their own could be exploited to a certain degree.

I got a similar but different story. I was in a game with a friend and his new in-game friend. His friend fed insanely top lane (insanely meaning he went 1-17...). We've all had bad games, but he died 40 seconds in to a SOLO kill to the enemy top laner. I had a great game of 17-4-4 and still couldn't carry because the top and bottom lanes were so insanely fed on their team. 

Anyways long story short I end up **blocking** (on friend list) the top laner from my team so he can never ask me to play again in case I forget who he was. As the previous game he was jungle and kept getting executed by the camps all the way up to level 6... I gave him a second chance because he was a friend of a friend.

So after I block him I make a new game. Guess who is top of the list of suggested players? The person I just blocked...

Good suggestion...

Agreed. Same thing happened to me last night. Not only that, it was almost the exact team playing together - only 1 new player. How does that happen? In the first game, the player was aggressive with put downs and then started feeding by just running the champ down lane into turrets. 

The second game was a little better, but the player was still reported for verbal abuse in the champ select as they mouthed off and referred to players in a derogatory manner. 

As mentioned in the comments, the simple solution is just to take a break for 5 minutes. I like this idea as it's probably best after a rough experience anyway. We are independent ,free-thinking beasts; the world doesn't need to be automated around us. 

Some are posting that the solution in the original post would be open to abuse. Maybe, but it wouldn't need to be an absolute. A timer, or one game skip, might suffice to get the players out sync and not in the same queues. I have hope that toxic players aren't that way all the time (otherwise they must live miserable lives!). 

My final thought on this is that I just wish players had greater respect for their team mates **time**. A couple of games of league can get you close to 2 hours of play, if not more. We are all busy folk, with work and study and family commitments. There is nothing worse than having an individual disrespect that through AFK, feeding or abuse. I make no claims to be expert player (i'm sitting on a horrible 10 game losing streak right now :/)  and we all have rough games or want to try new champs. In short we are all learning. A genuine commitment to getting better is evident in a player, as is a genuine commitment to making other players unhappy.

That would increase queue times outrageously.  I've reported like 50 people in my entire league career, and I don't report players very often.  Think of someone who has 200 or 300 people reported.

If ONE of those 200 or 300 people gets queued into 8 other people, leaving one spot open in the match making process, it will get filled by the next person to queue up, not you.  Which means you have to wait twice as long, for the next 9 players who you haven't reported queue up.

It doesn't sound that bad, but think of the huge web of player-reportingship that is in existence.  It'd be hard to get a game.

ESPECIALLY in higher ranks, when the queue times are much higher.  Think of all the challenger players that have to wait 20+ minutes for a game.  If they have 1 person reported, they might have to wait ANOTHER 20 minutes.

Honestly, the best thing to do is wait just 1 extra minute.  That's all it takes; just browse the shop and check your champion mastery and that person has probably already queued into a different lobby.

And chances are, since he isn't currently banned from being reported, he was just in a bad mood at the time.  Next week he'll probably be an unnoteworthy teammate not saying anything, or maybe even NICE.  But you won't play with him because you don't like it when he's angry.
